article_title: Legislative session winding down with mood of compromise
article_text:
Legislative session winding down with mood of compromise Observers note compromises allow all factions to claim major victories

Photo: Eric Gay, STF Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, center, talks to a guest in the Senate...

AUSTIN - With deals close on tax cuts, border security and other key issues as the legislative session heads into its final two weeks, jockeying intensified on the critical matter of who would claim political victory.

article_metadata.description: AUSTIN - With deals close on tax cuts, border security and other key issues as the legislative session heads into its final two weeks, jockeying intensified on the critical matter of who would claim political victory.  "If everything plays out as it appears it will right now, (House Speaker) Joe Straus will have had a good session because nothing passed that would endanger his coalition of centrist conservatives, Republicans, and Democrats," said Mark Jones, a Rice University political science professor who watches legislative action as meticulously as baseball fans watch the weekly stats.  By Saturday, Senate and House negotiators reported again that they were "very close" to an agreement on tax cuts, opting for property-tax relief by increasing the homestead exemption to $25,000 and reducing the business franchise tax by 25 percent.  On border security, negotiators by Saturday were reported to be close to a compromise that would keep state police and a limited number of National Guard troops on the Texas-Mexico border to target drug running, human trafficking and to help curb crossings by undocumented immigrants.  While the Senate and House have taken different approaches to reshaping ethics enforcement of state officials, including lawmakers, both have moved to strip the Public Integrity Unit, the state's ethics watchdog, from Travis County District Attorney's Office and move it to the Texas Rangers.  Republicans generally believe the unit has a partisan bent against them in Travis County, still a stronghold of local Democrat officeholders, and they are still fuming that one of them, District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg, refused to resign from office in 2013 after she was busted for drunken driving and served jail time.  Rick Perry, who was charged with official coercion and abuse of office for following through on a promise to veto state funding for the Public Integrity Unit if Lehmberg did not resign.  Barring a last-minute blowup, leaders in both chambers agree they expect an early announcement on tax cuts will presage a deal on the budget and the other issues - a conciliatory mood that contrasts with that early in the session, when the Senate and House appeared to be polar opposites on many issues.
article_metadata.author.name: By Mike Ward

Barring a last-minute blowup, leaders in both chambers agree they expect an early announcement on tax cuts will presage a deal on the budget and the other issues - a conciliatory mood that contrasts with that early in the session, when the Senate and House appeared to be polar opposites on many issues.
